subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Senator Parer) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 24 March, on motion by Senator Troeth:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI indicate on behalf of the opposition that we support the Gas Pipelines Access (Commonwealth) Bill 1998 . The bill introduces competition into our gas markets to prevent the abuse of market power or monopoly power. This is a process that Labor supports because we started it back in 1991 when Alan Griffiths, the then minister, initiated the national gas industry strategy. To its credit, the current government has continued that process, culminating in a COAG decision in November 1997 which set the scene for this legislation to be introduced and complementary legislation to be introduced in the various states and one territory.

speech.para: What is being sought here is competition to ensure that the cost of our energy, particularly the cost of our gas, is regionally and internationally competitive. This gives industry the best chance of being internationally and regionally competitive, particularly in areas of downstream processing. In any successful Australian resource or downstream processing project, the rule of thumb is: one-third of the cost of the project will go to manpower; one-third of the cost to infrastructure and other; and one-third of the cost to energy. Therefore, if you can ensure energy is competitively available, you have a greater chance of affecting downstream processing and resource development projects occurring in Australia.

The great challenge for our minerals and petroleum resource industries, and for policy makers, is to ensure that the great tradition we have had in Australia of being a bulk commodity exporter turns to our being a great downstream processor and adder of value. That means you need to turn iron ore into hot briquettes and/or steel, turn bauxite into alumina and aluminium, and down the value adding road you go. Energy is a very important, indeed vital, part of that process.

Competition will be introduced by ensuring that producers of gas have fair and reasonable access on commercial terms to the pipeliners or the transmitters of gas. There are three parts of the gas cycle: wellhead production, transmission and distribution. There is already significant competition at the production end, particularly offshore, largely because of competitive bidding for petroleum exploration and production licences. However, it has invariably been the case that monopolies, public or private, have existed in the transmission of gas. There is a need, therefore, to introduce competition into the transmission of gas so that the transmittersâif they are in such a monopoly positionâare effectively compelled under these arrangements to let a range of producers have access to the pipeline at fair and transparent rates.

If you dissect the levels of competition in the wellhead production area, the transmission area and the distribution area, historically one of the great hidden areas of mark-up here has been in the distribution and retail areas. The next step of the competition process needs to be at the distribution or the retail end. This bill reflects all those things.

While the opposition supports the bill and its passage now, there are a number of other matters on which we would like a response from the government before the bill is finally passed. Firstly, with respect to taxation implications, it was clearly an intention of the intergovernmental agreement that transitional measures not carry with them an additional tax burden. This would not be met if a pipeline owner covered by the access code was adversely affected by capital gains tax or petroleum resource rent tax by virtue of being required to transfer the pipeline to another legal entity. It is not proposed that this be remedied by amendment to this bill, but the opposition would like to know the government's attitude to the representations that have been made to it via the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, by APPEA, the relevant industry association, on this point. This issue needs to be addressed and fixed consistently with the intergovernmental agreement, and we support its resolution by the government consistent with clause 12.3 of the bill.

Secondly, with respect to appeal rights, the opposition would like to know the government's attitude to a recent submission circulated by the Law Council of Australia which points to an inconsistency in relation to appeals from decisions of the Australian Competition Tribunal under the Trade Prac tices Act. We raise this issue at this time only by way of enquiry. The government has provided the opposition with its legal advisers' response to the Law Council of Australia's submission. On the basis of that response, we are not proposing to move any differing view from that contained in the legislation, but we would be interested in hearing the minister's formal response during the debate in this chamber.

Thirdly, I note that the Western Australian legislation, recently introduced into the Western Australian Legislative Assembly, is to be considered in that parliament's autumn session, and consideration will be given to representation from sections of the Western Australian industry as to Western Australian variations, if any, from the national legislative model. For the record, as expressed in the House of Representatives, the opposition would like to be sure that industry and state consultation did occur in the crafting of the government's amendments adopted in the other place. The opposition has not received any representation on these amendments, which on the face of them, we acknowledge, appear to be minor.

Finally, I note that the government has indicated to industry that the proposed gas industry regulation levy bill will not be proceeded with. It is important that the regulation is adequately resourced and we look forward to industry and government suggestions on this point. In conclusion, the opposition supports the bill. We started the process and we look forward to seeing it finished.

talk.start.para: âI wish to thank Senator Forshaw for his contribution to this debate, and I also wish to comment on the addendum to the explanatory memorandum regarding the operation of clause 20 of the bill. I table an addendum to the revised explanatory memorandum relating to this bill. This deals with the taxation aspects of ring fencing of pipeline operations from other activities. The Commonwealth, states and territories have agreed as a general principle that there should be neither a benefit nor a loss to pipeline operators in meeting their obligations to separate pipeline oper ations from other activities. With regard to income tax, the new paragraph in the explanatory memorandum clarifies the government's intention that clause 20 will have no application in relation to income tax. I commend the bill to the Senate.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

debateinfo.title: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1997

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 24 March, on motion by Senator Troeth:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 seeks to amend quite a number of acts. For the record, they are the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act, the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act, the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act, the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act, the Dairy Produce Act, the Farm Household Support Act, the Fisheries Administration Act, the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act, the Pig Industry Act, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act, the Primary Industry Council Act, the Wheat Marketing Act, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997.

speech.para: I am sure honourable senators will be pleased that I do not intend to speak in detail on each of the amendments that relates to each of those acts. I am tempted to but, as the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) and Senator Calvert know, I am always short and to the point. Consequently, I will direct my remarks to those particular aspects of the bill that are of concern to the opposition.

I might just say, however, that there are a whole range of amendments contained in this bill affecting each of those acts. They go to such things as giving these bodies full responsibility for the employment of their chief executive officers. That is achieved by removing the legislative requirement for the minister to approve the terms and conditions of employment, including remuneration of the principal employee. The amendments specifically prohibit the organisations, many of which are governed by those acts I read out, from delegating the responsibility. There are also amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act and to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act which we are supportive of.

In the broad, the opposition supports the legislation, but there are two particular areas to which we wish to turn our attention. In due course we will be moving an amendment to delete provisions from the bill relating to the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation. The minister is aware of the issue that I am raising because the legislation, in respect of this particular section, was considered by the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee, and a report was issued in June dealing with this particular matter.

The effect of the bill specifically in this regard is to reduce the amount of money that would be available and paid to the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation by some $3.6 million. The explanatory memorandum states in respect of this part of the bill:

The amendment to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Corporation Act 1989 reduces the Commonwealth's contribution to the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation in the 1997-98 financial year by $3.612 million. Of the savings, $1.5 million is to go to the adjustment program for the South East Fishery and the balance towards helping to pull back the Budget deficit.

The saving is made possible because the Corporation's sound financial management has left it with substantial reserves. It is also considered that the saving will leave the Corporation with sufficient funds to continue operations and will not affect research priorities in the long term.

The Government remains a strong supporter of fisheries research and has set aside almost $8 million of Commonwealth funds in the budget under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 for fisheries research.

This part of the legislation, as I said, was considered by the Senate legislation committee. In a dissenting report, my colleague Senator O'Brien and I indicated that we did not agree with that part of the legislation. We do not support the reduction in research and development funding that would be involved here. Accordingly, we will be proposing an amendment to delete clauses 44 and 45 from the bill. That would have the effect of ensuring that the payment would continue.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.00 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Yesterday, in answer to a question from Senator Jacinta Collins, the minister told the Senate that she thought a case of benefits being cut because dependent children had been transferred from Austudy to youth allowance was `rather strange'. Is the minister aware that Centrelink have confirmed to a veteran in Launceston who is in receipt of a disability support pensionâ
âWhat is his name?

âHis name is Mr Bullock, for your information, Senator Macdonaldâthat his entitlements have been cut because his 17-year-old son has been transferred from Austudy to youth allowance? Is this cut in support for this constituent an unintended consequence of the government's introduction of the youth allowance; and has the minister investigated this and rectified these `rather strange' consequences of this government's policies?

âMadam President, I raise a point of order. Again, this is about the fifth occasion on which we have had supposed case studies or case histories. After that absolute fiasco the other day when Senator Carr tabled the document which demonstrated that what he was putting forward was based on a totally false and misleading impression of the circumstances of the family in question, then it is dangerous in the extreme to allow questions to be asked that may provide an entirely different picture of the circumstances to that of the reality. In those circumstances, Senator Murphy and others ought to be required to provide full details, or not be allowed to ask hypothetical questions.
âSenator Alston, there is no point of order.

âIn answer to the senator's question, I have been advised by Centrelink that, contrary to the government's intentions and as a result of a systems error, some customers have received reduced pensions with the introduction of the youth allowanceâand of course it was not part of the policy at all. Approximately 6,000 disability support, aged and single parenting payment pensioners had rates reduced by approximately $6 a fortnight, I am informed, and that affects their pension payments today.

answer.para: Centrelink have advised me that they are working on this problem and will fix the system tonight, 9 July. I am concerned, of course, for the people that this has happened to. But I am advised that the system will be processing the affected cases and will pay arrears to the affected customers by Wednesday of next week.

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the evidence that the minister provided yesterday to the Senate relating to the business dealings of a former Prime Minister which has significant implications for parliamentary standards and also the protection of the Commonwealth's revenue base. Can the minister inform the Senate of any new information he has received about Mr Keating's sale of his 50 per cent share in his piggery that has implications for the Commonwealth government and for the protection of our revenue base?

âYes. What I was criticising yesterday was the way in which the opposition, the Australian Labor Party, believed that it was legitimate to attack Senator Parer claiming that he was using a family trust as a tax dodge. Without any evidence of either tax avoidance or tax evasion, we had Labor senators, one after another, coming in here and attacking him in this way.

answer.para: Senator Faulkner accused him of having a dodgy pension scheme. Senator Murphy also picked it up and accused him of having a dodgy pension scheme. Senator Cook said that it amounted to a web of deceit, that it was a tax avoidance arrangement. And so one can go on. Senator Conroy was in it. Senator Ray was in it. He is not here today? He usually comes late, I know. He said it was a tax lurk. No reason, no evidence, no nothingâhe said it was a tax lurk.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I raise a point of order. I know that you have been trying to enforce your ruling that remarks of a minister in answering a question be addressed through the chair. I would ask you to ensure on this occasion that Senator Hill does that. We are very happy for Senator Hill, of course, to trot out the many and varied sins and incompetencies of the minister for resources. But I would ask you that, as he does so, as he runs through that list of failures on the part of the minister for resources, he does so through the chair.
âSenator Hill, I remind you of the standing orders.

âCertainly, Madam President. What I am doing is explaining the double standards of those of the Australian Labor Party. Therefore, presumably they are just as interested in the affairs of their previous Prime Minister, if there is evidence of managing those affairs in a way to minimise tax.

answer.para: It is true that I received overnight a trust statement relating to the sale of Mr Keating's 50 per cent interest in his piggery.

talk.start.para: âWho from?

âUnder the name of his solicitors, Gaden's Ridgeway, it indicates that $6,376,647.30 was paid inâand we know that the transaction was a $6 million transaction; we learnt that yesterday. But what is interesting is that the stamp duty that was paid was just under $5,000. That stamp duty equates to a sale of less than $1 million. So, at the very least, it evidences the fact that Mr Keating conducted his affairs in a way to minimise tax.

answer.para: Are those of the Labor Party going to get up here and accuse Mr Keating of a dodgy scheme, of a tax lurk, of tax avoidance arrangements? Of course they will not because that is one of their own; that would be to criticise one of their own. Senator Faulkner, if it is good enough for Senator Parer when you have no evidence, it is certainly good enough for Mr Keating when there is a bundle of evidence. I table the document to which I have referred.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the minister aware that a constituent of hers and mine, a resident of Georgetown in Tasmania, will lose up to $100 a fortnight from her social security benefits as a result of being assessed as a dependent under the new youth allowance scheme? Is the minister aware that this constituent, who is 17 years old, lives with her partner and is expecting a child, has been advised by Centrelink she will be required to leave that relationship and return to her parent's house as a dependent child in order to access assistance? Is the minister further aware that an adviser in her Launceston office advised the constituent's mother that nothing could be done for her daughter? Can the minister confirm that the constituent was told that the minister could not change the law and anyway her predicament was `not my problem'?

âI would certainly refute the aspersion that has been cast on the member of my staff, because I am sure that the person whom you are referring to has been giving caring and considerate attention to constituents for all the years she has been working for me. Having said that, I have already made it clear to the Senate that I will not make determinations on claimants for social security in this chamber, partly because so often senators in opposition have not given the full story or, alternatively, because the full story has not been given to them by a constituent. If you are happy to, Senator, after question time, I would be very glad to take the details from you and have it further investigated.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I have a letter from the constituent's mother which confirms the points I have made, and I am happy to supply you with a copy of that. Is the minister aware that her Launceston office also advised the writer of the letter that Senator Newman would not be available for an appointment because `she now resides in Canberra'? Is this true?
âNow I know you're lying, Senator.
âSenator Newman, perhaps you could phrase it differently. Withdraw that remark.

âI will rephrase it to the extent that I know that no member of my staff would say it because it is not true. Like you, Senator, I have been locked up in this place for far too many weeks. We would all like to be home with our constituents.

âMy question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can the leader inform the Senate of any additional information received from Indonesia regarding Mr Keating's multi-million dollar piggery deal, which has implications for parliamentary standards and the protection of the Commonwealth's revenue base? What would be the capital gains tax implications of such a transaction that he may wish to outline?

âMadam President, I rise on a point of order. A number of points of order have been taken in this chamber recently about hypothetical questions. I think they have been taken wrongly and unfairly, but on this occasion I draw your attention to the question that Senator Abetz has asked and ask you to rule it out of order. It is quite clearly contrary to standing orders. That is a hypothetical question.

âOn the point of order, I remind Senator Faulkner and the Senate that I am not asking anything that is hypothetical. I am talking about additional information actually received, not fabricated like those from the other side. This is actual information received which has implications for parliamentary standards. That is clearly within the province of the Leader of the Government to answer. I also asked about the protection of the Commonwealth's revenue base. That is also something clearly within the province of the Leader of the Government to comment upon. So, Madam President, clearly all elements of the question are in order.
âI believe that the question is in order but the manner of answering it may indicate a breach of the standing orders. I will deal with that if that is the case.

âThe point is that the Australian Labor Party have been making a big issue of conflict of interest and, to use Senator Robert Ray's expression, perceived conflict of interest. They have attacked our side and they have attacked our ministers on the basis of what they say is conflict of interest.

answer.para: In the case of Mr Keating, he was Prime Minister of this country when he was conducting this highly complex set of arrangementsâhe was selling his half interest in his pig venture to Indonesian businessmen while at the same time he was negotiating a defence treaty with the President of Indonesia. This is as a Prime Minister dealing with the highest matters of state with Indonesia while at the same time he was negotiating the sale of his piggery interest to Indonesians. What about a conflict of interest or perceived conflict of interest in that regard?

Yes, we have received further information from Indonesia overnight. That information purports to be a statement of record of what Mr Keating's solicitor instructed in relation to dealing with the transaction.

talk.start.para: âShould he not have signed the treaty?
âSenator Carr, cease interjecting!
âI have caused inquiries to be made this morning upon which I believe that the statement is authentic.
âOh, you believe, do you?
âThe first paragraph states:

answer.para: "HE"â
that is, His Excellency Mr Keatingâ
is to sell the half-ownership of the Parkville and Glengallan piggeries to William Soeryadjaya for a purchase price of US$6,000,000.
It goes on, at item 2:
In order to reduce tax liability and to avoid any possible political backlashesâ
Senator Carrâ
the payment of the US$6 mil is structured in the following manner:
It goes on to a series of structures. It tells us how the first instalment of $2.5 million would be divided into a direct fund transfer. Then it goes on to say:

The remaining US$1.9 mil would be treated in a way that it would look like an equity injection of the same amount to the company, whereas it would actually be channelled out of the company for the benefit of "HE".
The document then talks about the remaining $3.5 million, which it says would not be recorded in any official document.

talk.start.para: âSo you would not have signed the treaty.

âConflicts of interest! What does the Labor Party say about this? This was going on while this man was the Labor Prime Minister of Australia. Out of the Prime Minister's office he was seeking to sell his business to the Indonesians at the same time as he was negotiating defence treaties with the Indonesians. All this evidence suggests at the very least that he was conducting that transaction in a way to minimise taxation consequences and to minimise any political embarrassment. This is a serious matter and it should be considered as a serious matter. To further assist in that consideration, I table the document to which I have referred.
âMy question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy.
âOrder! Senators on my right will behave in a way that will let Senator Parer hear this question.

âI refer to the minister's statement yesterday that he had made clear to his staff the need to comply with the Prime Minister's directive to not participate in the Telstra share offer within 90 days of the float. Has he therefore sought details from his media adviser about the 1,600 Telstra shares Mr Baudino sought during the public offer which were registered in Mr Baudino's own name on 25 November 1997? What possible legitimate excuse could the minister's staff member have for this flagrant and deliberate breach of the Prime Minister's directive? Or what remedial action does the minister propose to take? Does the minister propose to extend the East Court defence to his staff now: blame your wife, blame your accountant, blame someone else but never take the responsibility yourself?
âI think you just breached the standing orders, Senator.
âFollowing the question raised by Senator Faulkner yesterday, I immediately initiated a thorough investigation into the claims made by him. Those investigations are going on.
âHow long does it take?

âYou want to shoot from the hip like Sid Vicious over there. Those investigations are going on, and they are thorough. As part of that investigation, contact was made with Mr Baudino's stockbroker. The advice to date does not confirm the assertion of Senator Faulkner in his virulent adjournment speech last night. I will read from the letter to Mr Baudino from his stockbroker:

answer.para: Further to our telephone discussion, I confirm that you advised me of the guidelines regarding Telstra. I ensured you did not acquire shares in the float through your personal account, which I handle myself. I did not think it necessary to issue an instruction that Telstra shares were not to be acquired through the RL and OM Baudino investment account which, as you are aware, is operated on instructions from Mrs Baudino and your accountant.

The Telstra shares in question were acquired through the public issue and, accordingly, the application was lodged by Henderson Charlton Jones Telstra processing unit and not handled by an individual adviser. As you will appreciate, there were over 10,000 applications processed by Henderson Charlton Jones for the Telstra issue. The original application for Telstra was made in RL and OM Baudino investment account. To our knowledge, it has been in that name and has not been transferred at any stage.

talk.start.para: âIt was once.
âNo. Something went wrong.

âThat is what the minister always says. Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that the registered address of Mr Baudino's shareholding is Mr Baudino's home address and not the accountant's office? Is it not the case that the Telstra shareholding statement as well as the dividend advice statement in respect of dividends paid by Telstra on 31 March this year were sent to the registered shareholders' address as contained on the Telstra shareholder register? Does the minister stand by Mr Baudino's claim that he had no knowledge of his ownership of Telstra shares?

âI refer Senator Faulkner to the letter from one of the most respected stockbrokers in Queensland in response to part of that question. With regard to the other issues raised by Senator Faulkner, they will be part of the fairly thorough investigation that is going on.

âMy question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. There has been media coverage of some Liberals being concerned with One Nation's compliance with the Commonwealth Electoral Act. My question concerns bogus how-to-vote cards. Is the minister aware of the controversy surrounding the use of a bogus One Nation how-to-vote card by the Labor Party in the Queensland seat of Mansfield which was widely reported last weekend? If not, is the minister aware of a now infamous Nunawading incident in Victoria involving a bogus Nuclear Disarmament Party how-to-vote card and even a bogus Australian Democrats how-to-vote card used in the New South Wales seat of Robertson a few elections back? Does the minister agree that the use of these style of cards, which are intentionally designed to mislead and to pass off one thing as another, are now such a regular occurrence that voters should enjoy protection in law against their use?
âObviously we would be totally opposed to any use of such a card.
âCommenting on a current court matter; you wouldn't do that, would you?

âThat is why I am a little delicate in my management of this. We are opposed to the use of a card which, to quote the senator, is `intentionally designed to mislead'. Every honourable senator would be opposed to it. The issue raised in the question was whether this practice had become so widespread that it justified legislative change. That is a matter that I wish to take up with the minister responsible for the electoral laws. Without doing that, it would also require an analysis of the capacity of the existing laws to deal with it. I will pursue the matter with the appropriate minister. We might be able to give Senator Murray some further response in due course.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, thank you for that answer. I raised the question because of the recent publicity about the Liberals being concerned with One Nation. Is the minister aware that last week, in fact, your government rejected a number of Democrats' amendments to the Electoral Act which sought to improve the regulation of the use of how-to-vote cards in elections? Doesn't the minister agree that any possible challengeâfor instance, the Mansfield caseâcould again reveal a problem in this area? I ask the minister: will the coalition now reconsider their support for legislation to protect voters against future acts of deliberate deception via bogus how-to-vote cards which, in our view, are fast becoming common?

âI have said that I would take the question on notice and give the honourable senator a considered reply. I think the supplementary question really repeated the substance of the principal question, and that is: has this matter become so commonplace that it requires a legislative response and is the government prepared to so legislate? That is a matter that I will take on notice and give the response, as I had indicated.

âMy question is directed to Senator Hill as the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can the minister assure the Senate that no member of the Prime Minister's staff, employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act, purchased Telstra Corporation shares, as required by the Prime Minister's directive? Is it not the case that, for a minister as closely involved with Telstra privatisation matters as the Prime Minister, this prohibition is not limited to the 90-day period that is relevant to other ministers? I ask: what measures did the Prime Minister take to ensure that his own staff understood the directive and fully complied with it?

âIt will not come as a surprise if I confess to honourable senators that I have not studied the share register. I do not know who purchased Telstra shares. Obviously, I cannot, therefore, give the assurance that is being sought of me, but I will refer the matter to the Prime Minister. I presume there is some basis for the question and, therefore, the substance of the matter will be investigated.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister aware that Mr Geoffrey Ashton Cousins of Kirribilli, New South Wales, purchased 600 shares in the Telstra float? Is the minister also aware that Mr Cousins disposed of his Telstra shares on or about 30 December 1997 with a stag profit of some 66 per cent for holding them for five weeks? Is the minister aware that the same Mr Cousins is employed by the Prime Minister under Part 2 of the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act, and is listed as a Communications Strategist to the Prime Minister in the Parliament House communications directory? In light of these revelations, how is it possible for Mr Cousins to have complied with the Prime Minister's directive?

âI have already said that I do not know whether any member of the staff of the Prime Minister purchased shares, either consistent with the directive or in breach of the directive. I have said that I would have the matter investigated and report back in due course.

âMy question is to Senator Hill, Minister representing the Treasurer. As the minister would be aware, as part of the national competition policy legislative review process, the National Competition Council is overseeing a review of state agreement acts with a view to seeing whether they are anti-competitive. Western Australia, which has about 120 of these acts, which read like a list of Western Australia's biggest environmental disasters, has argued that these acts should be exempt from competition policy. The list includes the Woodchipping Industry Agreement Act, the Iron and Steel (Mid West) Agreement Actâthat is, Oakajeeâand the Silicon (Kemerton) Agreement Act. As these acts generally include subsidies involving tax or royalty holidays, subsidised infrastructure, guaranteed buy-backs or cheap energy, I ask the minister why this indicative review process has not involved any public consultation. The WA Treasury has suggested to me that it might scare off investors if the WA public got a chance to comment on where large chunks of their money is going. Does the minister agree?

âI thought that Senator Margetts might ask me this question today, but only thought of it shortly before question time. I have somewhat of a response for her. On the last part of the question, I find it hard to accept that the Treasury would suggest what she has put to the Senate. But, without that little bit of editorialising, I would respond that, as she knows, the competition principles agreement is an inter-governmental agreement on national competition policy which the Commonwealth and all state and territory governments signed up to in April 1995. As part of the competition principles agreement, all parties agreed to undertake a legislative review process whereby they would review all legislation which restricts competition.

answer.para: As I understand it, it is not a question of the NCC reviewing the state legislation; it is the state accepting to review its own legisla tion. The guiding principle of these reviews is that legislation should not restrict competition unless it can be demonstrated that the benefits of the restriction to the community as a whole outweigh the costs and that the objectives of that legislation can only be achieved by restricting competition.

According to the competition principles agreement between the Commonwealth and the state and territory governments, each party is free to determine its own agenda for the reform of legislation that restricts competition. Competition policy does not prescribe outcomes, it only demands that all legislative restrictions to competition are subject to a public benefit test and that all legislative restrictions on competition are fully transparent at the end of the day.

There has recently been some discussion about what constitutes `public benefit'. The term should be regarded in its widest possible sense, and would include anything of value to the community generally. I hope that is of assistance to Senator Margetts.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for the information so far. Senator Hill mentioned public benefits outweighing the costs. I believe that well-known consultants ACIL Economics had been involved in the process of reviewing state agreement acts on behalf of Western Australia and the Department of Resources Development. Is it not the case, Minister, that the public would actually appreciate the ability to put in information about whether public benefits and public cost are balanced, or equal, or in any way relevant? Would it not save the Commonwealth money if the public were involved in this process, so that the information in the review is accurate? Isn't giving the Department of Resources Development in Western Australia the role of reviewing their own acts, which they do not want reviewed, a case of leaving Dracula in charge of the blood bank?
âAs I understand it, the determination is made by the Western Australian government, and I really think that Senator Margetts should take her complaint up with the Western Australian government.
âIt is your legislation.

âShe can argue out with the Western Australian government whether there is a public benefit in each individual case. Whether a public contribution to that decision making process would be useful is obviously something on which different people will have a different view. The determination as is being adopted in Western Australia is by the Western Australian government and, as I understand it, that is within the terms of the agreement that was reached between the Commonwealth and the states.

âMy question is directed to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. Can the minister confirm that, as required by the Prime Minister's code of ministerial conduct, at the time of commencing their employment ministerial consultants and members of ministers' staff are required to complete statements of private interests and, further, that the employing minister endorses the statement in writing after satisfying him or herself that there is no conflict of interest? Can the minister confirm that the Prime Minister's senior economic adviser, Mr Peter Crone, complied with these requirements when he joined the Prime Minister's staff late last year? Did Mr Crone declare his 1,000 Telstra shares and did the Prime Minister endorse Mr Crone's declaration? Can the minister also confirm that Mr Crone has, in the course of his responsibilities as senior economic adviser, been intimately involved in government deliberations relating to the privatisation of Telstra?
âI do not know Mr Crone, let alone what shares he owns. But I will refer the question to the Prime Minister and get a response.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Isn't it the case that, according to the government's guidelines for staff, a staff member who possesses an interest which conflicts or might reasonably be thought to conflict with the duties of his or her office has three choices: to divest the interest forthwith, to secure his or her removal from the duties in question or to obtain authorisation from his or her superior or colleagues to continue to discharge the duties? I ask: which of these three choices did Mr Crone make?
âIt logically follows that I cannot answer that without referring to the Prime Minister. I will get a response as soon as possible.

âMy question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Minister, can you inform the Senate what steps the government is taking to ensure that regional mobile phone users do not lose out as a result of Labor's disastrous 1992 decision to unilaterally phase out the analog AMPS mobile phone system in the year 2000? Minister, how does this initiative build on the series of measures which the Howard government has introduced to improve the lives of Australian fixed and mobile telephone users in its two years in power?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe contrast could not be more stark. Since we have been in government, in a little over two years not only have we made dramatic improvements for rural and regional users of telecommunications servicesârolling out an ISDN capability to enable them to get high-speed access to the Internet, improving customer service guarantees, maintaining price caps and, in a whole range of ways, ensuring that the universal service obligation is fully complied withâbut, over and above that, one of the biggest problems we inherited was the `absolutely disastrous' decision, as Senator Ferguson quite rightly describes it, made by none other than Mr Beazley, the relevant communications minister of the day.

answer.para: This was a technology specific decision. It was utterly oblivious to the real needs of rural users. It had no regard whatsoever to what might happen in the future in terms of new technologies. We have not heard a single word of apology for it ever sinceânot one word. All they have ever done is get out there and oppose, tooth and nail, things like our $250 million Networking the Nation initiative designed to at least try to assist people to get local Internet points of presence and to provide additional base stations for mobile telephone services.

It is, I think, an historic achievement that today we are in a position to announce that the Telstra board has agreed to roll-out a new technology called CDMAâCode Division Multiple Accessâwhich will cover all the existing analog areas, be fully compatible with existing AMPS networks and enable people to have a dual-mode handset. It will move seamlessly between the new digital technology and the old analog technologies. In other words, Madam President, in one fell swoop we are wiping out your disaster. It is their disaster, not yours, Madam President. You have done an excellent job, I hasten to add.

The Labor Party made this decision, led by the minister for communications, the now Leader of the Opposition, in the full knowledge that it would require people who live in rural areas to have two mobile phones: an analog phone when they were near analog based stations and a digital phone when they came to the cities. That is the result that would occur after the year 2000.

Why would they possibly do it, Madam President? Presumably because they could not give a damn about the bush. They were not interested in the consequences for consumers. I hope that at least they will have the decency to acknowledge that this decision today will go a very substantial way towards repairing that damage. It will make a huge difference to people who want to be in the 21st century and want to get decent and up-to-date mobile telephone services. They will still have to wait around for what I think will be a new digital era of low earth orbiting satellites but, in the meantime, they want to have the best access to mobile services.

This is very important step forward. It is a damning indictment of what Labor did. They have never apologised in all those seven long years. I hope that they will now have the decency to put out a press release supporting it, but I very much doubt it.

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware of a booklet about child-care services circulated in June by the parliamentary secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services, Trish Worth MP? Is he aware of the attached graph that shows that Commonwealth outlays on child care increasing each year from 1989-90 to 2000-2001? Does the minister concede that the graph is incorrect and that the real figures show child-care expenditure dropping substantially in 1997-98, in fact to well below their level in 1995-96, being the last year of the Labor government?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI am very happy to reply to that question. There is good news in child care that the government has brought about. Some $4.7 billion has been allocated to child care over four years and there is an extra 71,000 places over that time. There are currently 495,000 families using formal child care and 600,000 children in care. By 2001-2002 allocations for child care will be 30 per cent higher than in Labor's last year of office.

answer.para: I am not familiar with the booklet that has been referred to, but the facts that I have just given would refute the general principle that is being proposed. The improved affordability that we have introduced for low and middle income families using outside child-care services will result in 71,000 families benefiting. Better planning has been introduced to ensure that child-care services will be established in areas of greatest need. Also better equity has been introduced by the withdrawal of the operational subsidy. For example, operational subsidy in community based centres meant that some 70,000 families received a $20 benefit denied to 200,000 Australian families using private centres.

There is a continued commitment to quality. The government supports quality assurance in long day care services and the development of systems for family day care and outside school hours care. There is better information for families. The child-care access hotlineâfreecall 1800 670 305âprovides up-to-date information for families about child-care services in their area and government help with the cost of care.

I will check with Trish Worth as to the accuracy of the graph that has been referred to, but I am sure that the overall figures that I have just given the honourable senator are correct. There is no question about the funding that is being provided or the improvements that will be brought about. I contrast those improvements with Labor's legacy in child care. Not only did the government inherit a $10.5 billion debt and a $70 billion debt in the preceding seven years but the child-care industry was in disarray through Labor's poor management.

From 1991 private child-care centres established in locations with no direction or support from government to indicate areas of greatest need. There was haphazard growth all over the country. Too many centres now exist in certain areas, creating an oversupply, while other areas have a great need and an undersupply. This poorly planned access to child care has created uncertainty in the child-care industry about their future viability due to too many centres in some areas.

I think we should bring this to the Senate's attention because, under Labor, the low rate of child-care assistance provided to families in outside school hours care was totally inadequate to the needs of low and middle income families. Labor effectively prevented 51,000 families in outside school hours care from receiving any child-care assistance. Labor left us with a poorly planned child-care industry. The Howard government is fixing the foundations to provide better access for families to quality child care.

If Labor want to play cheap politics in child care, spreading misinformation and developing so-called surveys to suit their political agenda, I ask them what their policies are in relation to child care. Have we heard one word? They got it in disarray. They have not produced any policies. There is some nitpicking going on about some graph or other, which I will check to see whether the statement that has just been proposed is accurate. We were left a legacy of disarray. We put the foundations in to fix it up and we are spending much more money to produce those changes. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. When the minister confirms what is contained in his own government's budget documentsâthat expenditure in child care has substantially dropped in 1997-98âwhat will the minister do to inform those people who have been misled by the parliamentary secretary about what the real facts in child care are?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable senator for the supplementary question. Talk about misinformation! I refer her to the Blacktown Advocate of Wednesday, 29 April, which states:

answer.para: Publicity surrounding federal government cuts to child-care funding has hurt local private child-care centres even though they never received the subsidy. Owner of Blacktown's Maldon kindergarten, Dick Leathers, said, "The recent bad publicity on child care funding would hurtâ

talk.start.para: âMadam President, on a point of order: I thoughtâand I am sure you would agree with meâSenator Herron was asked a fairly specific supplementary question and he is not answering it at all. He is not even attempting to answer it. I ask you to direct him to do so.

âSenator Neal believes everything she reads. Contrary to the views expressed in some media articles, the 1998-99 child-care budget does not cut a further $117 million from child-care funding. Are you happy with that, Senator Faulkner? That is the answer to the supplementary question.

answer.para: The figures have simply been revised on the basis of additional information about growth in places and patterns of demand. talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Minister, are you aware of the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures released today showing that business investment in research and development fell in the first year of your government by five per cent, ending a six-year run of growth? Will you agree that the $700 million worth of cuts to R&D tax concessions have been a major cause of this damaging windback? And, Minister, while we are talking about business, can you explain why the number of bankruptcies in Australia last year rose by 13 per centâa record levelâand why bankruptcies have risen by 43 per cent since your government took office?

âIt is true that there was a small fall in R&D. I might say it was a smaller decline than what many critics suggested would be the case but, of course, it is partly attributable to the overdue removal of the excesses due to the syndication component of the R&D tax concessionâone of Labor's tax rorts, as we understand, that this government had to address.

answer.para: That ought to be balanced against the good prospects for investment in R&D for the future. In particular, I remind the Senate of the government's Investing for Growth statement of December last year, in which we committed $1 billion over a four-year period to encourage R&D growth. That is over a billion dollars, I repeat. Furthermore, the Investing for Growth statement commits substantial funds to the R&D start program. It also boosted the innovation investment fund. All of these will ultimately flow through and ensure that the R&D investment in this country is as strong as ever and, we would hope, stronger, in fact, than in the past.

It is obviously necessary. I think anyone who has studied the subject would be aware that, while governments in Australia have traditionally been quite strong in their expenditure on R&D, the private sector, historically, has not been so strong. That is why we have taken action to encourage the private sector to invest for the future through the R&D start program. But we are not doing it in a way in which it can be used as a tax rort.

So we are going through this process of change of structure, in effect, and I think that is the explanation for the small reduction that has occurred. In the long term, the prospects are good for Australian industry to be investing in research and development, which obviously is critical to maintaining a competitive edge.

We have set the framework for that investment in the future. We have set the macro-economic environment with low interest rates, low taxation and low inflation that will give businesses the confidence in which to invest for their future. The prospects for the economic growth that will build upon those economic decisions taken by the government and upon the incentive provided through the R&D start program will bring benefits in the medium to long term. I would have thought that was the objective that all honourable senators would seek.

talk.start.para: âMinister, in your answer you didn't touch at all on bankruptcies so I ask again: aren't you concerned that they are up 43 per cent? This is well before any of the suspected impact from what is happening in Asia occurs.
âSenators on my right will cease interjecting while a question is being asked.

âThank you. Through you, Madam President, I ask a supplementary question: isn't the minister concerned that business investment growth was halved last year and will fall by a third again this year? Isn't it the case that this government's mix of economic policies is simply not helping new businesses get established and is certainly not assisting existing businesses to grow and expand?

âThat, of course, is a nonsense. The government's policies are all about encouraging businesses to grow and expand and employ. They are employing more now than ever before. That approach has been successful. The GDP rose strongly in the March quarter, which is inconsistent with what the honourable senator said. As I said, to a background of low inflation, low interest rates and low taxation, finally we have got a government in office that is prepared to control taxation growth. It is a bit cheeky, I might say, for Senator Lees, who represents a party that supports high interest rates and high borrowings, to ask this question of a government that supports low taxation, low interest rates and low inflation. We have set the scene for growth and for more jobs, and that is our purpose.

âMy question is directed to Senator Vanstone, representing the Attorney-General. It is a question about privacy. When the government decided against a proposal to legislate to protect privacy in the private sector, did it ask the state governments not to implement like legislation? In any event, what attitude does the government take to Victoria's proposal to introduce privacy legislation in that state? What attitude does the government take to the recent recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit that the government introduce privacy legislation, with specific reference to information communications, to govern the use of personal information in the private sector?

âI thank Senator Cooney for the question. It will be no surprise to Senator Cooney when I tell him that the Attorney-General has not provided a brief with respect to any comments he might want to make about Victorian legislation. The reason it will not surprise Senator Cooney is that he knows full well that it is not the Attorney's job to sit and pontificate on what one state might choose to do over another.

answer.para: As to any discussions the Attorney might have had with the states in relation to what they might choose to do in the privacy areas or others, I will refer Senator Cooney's question to the Attorney. If he wants to comment on private discussions he might have had, I am sure he will provide information and I will pass that on.

The last part of Senator Cooney's question related to the findings of one of the Senate committees. In relation to any of those committees, the government would respond at a time it considered appropriate.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I put that to the minister to give a context to the question of whether or not the federal government intends to do something about privacy in the private sector. It is not only those issues that I have already raised. The minister may want to look at, for example, an article in the Financial Review of the weekend before last in which a reference was made to Qantas, which is about to introduce a multimillion dollar system that will digitally capture every word its sales staff utter on the telephone and every keystroke they enter on a computer. Qantas will also be able to listen to whatever the customers say to their staff. It is in that context that I would seek to find out from the minister whether or not the federal government intends to do anything about privacy in the private sector.

âSenator Cooney well understands the government's view with respect to this matter. This matter has been canvassed in this chamber on a number of occasions. I have not seen the particular article you are referring to but, as a matter of interest, I will look at it. I think you are indicating that you will be kind enough to send it to me and I would be grateful for thatâwith your usual charm.

answer.para: Senator Cooney, I understand you have a genuine interest in privacy matters. I only wish, when your party was in government, they had been more successful at protecting people's privacy. I know that some of the Australian Democrats also have a very strong interest in this issue. Where we differ is in the path we choose to follow to protect that privacy. That is the only difference. We are all at one in respect of the need to protect people's privacy; we simply have a difference of opinion about the best way to do it.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, my question is to Senator Vanstone, Minister for Justice. Minister, the Spanish government has refused to give Christopher Skase Spanish residency and has given him 15 days to leave the country. This action follows the successful cancellation and retrieval of the Australian passport given to Christopher Skase by the former Labor government. Does the cancellation of Mr Skase's Spanish residency mean he will be returning to Australia to face outstanding criminal charges? What is the minister's response to claims that the Australian government could reopen extradition proceedings? Is the government determined to pursue Skase and his assets?

âI thank Senator Calvert for his question. Yes, as I was pleased to announce last night, the Spanish government has indicated to Mr Skase that they will refuse him permanent residency and, as I am advised, indicated to him that he has 15 days in which to leave. Equally, I made it clear last night and this morning that Mr Skase has a couple of weeks in which to appeal that decision. He has already appealed an earlier decision by the Spanish government to refuse him Spanish identity documents. That whole process follows on from the cancellation of his Australian passportâthe new, 10-year, fresh Australian passportâgiven to him by the previous Labor government when he was in Spain and was wanted back in Australia.
âWhat does the Spanish government say, Amanda?
âIt follows the cancellation of that, the retrieval of it from the Spanish government and their refusal to provide identity documents.

answer.para: Senator Bolkus, in his usual form, has been out on the airwaves trying to cover up Labor's failures in this area and keeps saying, `Why don't they reopen the extradition?'ânot realising how stupid he looks in doing thatâ

talk.start.para: âYou can start new ones. You cannot be that dumb.

âWhen Mr Skase discarded the oxygen mask and the wheelchairâwe all remember thatâthe former Labor Attorney-General sought advice. That advice was clear and unequivocal that it just was not on to proceed with reopening the extradition. It is a bit like a murder trial, in a sense; you have your chance at the trial, one wins and one loses. When Labor was in power they were in charge of the extradition and they lost.
âThe Prime Minister told you to stop playing politics.
âSenator Bolkus, I would ask you to cease interjecting. You have been doing it throughout this answer.

âMadam President, I raise a point of order. The Prime Minister made it very clear this morning that Senator Vanstone should stop playing politics with this issue. I am just bringing that fact to your attention. It is relevant to her answer and it is something that she needs to take into account.
âThere is no point of order.

âSenator Bolkus knows full well that Mr Lavarch, the then Attorney-General, got two pieces of advice in 1995 following the failed extradition. He knows that that advice confirmed what I have just told you. This government has had that advice confirmed as well, and Senator Bolkus simply chooses to ignore this.

answer.para: The last part of the question was whether this government intends to continue the chase for Skase, made as hard as it is by the monumental failure in 1994. We do intend, unequivocally, to pursue this matter. I believe Australians very much resent ill-gotten wealth. We are a fairly fair-minded nation and we respect people who gain wealth through hard work and talent but have no respect for people who build up their assets by other means. Many people believe that Mr Skase built his fortune by squirrelling away what was, effectively, other people's money. Many people believe that he played fast and loose with other people's hard-earned money. What they want to see is the truth brought out in the Australian courts. They do not prejudge the matter, they want to see the truth brought out.

Australians have no respect for ill-gotten gains. That is why they are now asking how a former trade union official could become a multimillionaire on a politician's salary, like Paul Keating apparently did, and why they are asking: where did that money come from?

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Ellison, Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. âThe truth is that Winning Edge wrote a letter to my department, which stated:

answer.para: This letter is to confirm that Winning Edge continues to provide service in the Richmond and St Marys areas. The administration and pre-screening work for these two sites have been transferred to our offices in Mt Druitt and Penrith, however job seekers may still register and resumes will still be collected for job applications in all four sites.

Those two offices have not closed. This is yet another attempt by the opposition to mislead the public in relation to Job Network. These two offices have not closed. Equally, the member for Batman issued a misleading statement that these two offices had closed. They have not closedâI repeat: not closed. This is another attempt by the opposition simply to mislead the public on this issue.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Why is it then that there has been a reduction in services in two of these offices? It is alleged by the minister that they have not closed. But there is a reduction in service level. How many of these enterprises within the Job Network have also undertaken a reduction in services to the clients?
âAs Winning Edge has maintained, it is still operating four offices. It is still providing those services to job seekers. End of story.
âMadam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

âYesterday in question time, Senator Brown asked me, in my capacity as representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, a question in regard to the funding of the Hume Dam. The minister has now provided me with a response, and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
Senator Brown asked a question in the Senate on 8 July 1998 if up to $48m has been diverted from the MD2001 program to fund capital works on Hume Dam rather than being used for environmental purposes
Senator Brown has some fundamental misunderstandings about the role of Hume Dam, the Natural Heritage Trust and MDB initiative funding.
Hume Dam is central to the managed operations of River Murray flows to support sustainable agriculture, the people of SA in particular, and river and floodplain environments.

With regards to the Natural Heritage Trust Senator Brown implies use of trust funds for remedial works on Hume Dam falls outside the scope of the trust. He is ignoring the fact that trust funds are able to be spent for the purposes of supporting natural resource management and sustainable agriculture as well as the environment. I refer him to part 3 of the act.

With regard to the Natural Heritage Trust each Commonwealth dollar for MD2001 is matched in total by the states 1:1. However under MDB initiative arrangements for Hume Dam, each Commonwealth dollar attracts three state dollars (one each from NSW, Victoria and SA).

The necessary reallocation of $11.523m over four years is needed to ensure the Hume Dam is able to generate sustainable agriculture and environmental benefits. This reallocation will not result in the loss of $48m as asserted by Senator Brown.

I would like to emphasise to Senator Brown that the current federal budget allocates some $43m to MDB dedicated natural resource management programs. This continues an upward trend in such funding and compares to around $13.8m for similar activities in the last year of the Keating government.
Senator Brown has asked a related question on notice and further details will be provided in the response to that question.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
